item.title: MNE | Beijing calls for “mutual respect” after German minister’s visit is canceled
item.description: The Chinese Government defended yesterday that China and Germany must maintain relations based on “mutual respect, equal treatment and mutually beneficial cooperation”, after the postponement of a visit by the German Foreign Minister. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Guo Jiakun declared, at a press conference, that Beijing “has always developed ties with Berlin from a strategic and long-term perspective”. Guo stressed that, as “large countries and leading world economies”, China and Germany maintain a “mutually beneficial” cooperative relationship. “Under the current circumstances, both parties must continue to push their ties in the right direction,” he added. The German Ministry of Foreign Affairs confirmed last week the postponement of Johann Wadephul's visit, scheduled for October 28th and 29th, after the Chinese side did not confirm further meetings beyond the meeting with his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi. German diplomacy spokeswoman Kathrin Deschauer expressed Berlin's “great concern” about the restrictions imposed by Beijing on the export of certain components used in the production of semiconductors and rare earth materials, measures that raised alarm in the German automotive industry. Trade tensions between the two countries intensified after the intervention of the Dutch State in the chip manufacturer Nexperia, a subsidiary of the Chinese Wingtech, which led Beijing to restrict exports of crucial components for the sector. The ban is generating concern among the Volkswagen Group, Europe's largest car manufacturer.

item.title: Association leader says HK learns from Macau elections
item.description: Hong Kong is going to elections for the Legislative Council (LegCo), the local parliament, on December 7th and in connection with this event, Lo Man-tuen, president of the association China Peaceful Development General Summit of Hong Kong-Macao-Taiwan Diaspora, stated that the Hong Kong rulers have already gone to Macau to learn from the experiences of the last electoral act, which elected deputies via direct and indirect access to the Legislative Assembly (AL). This information was expressed in an opinion article published by the newspaper Ming Pao, where the leader highlights the high turnout of Macau voters at the polls, with a participation rate of 53.35 percent. Lo Man-tuen also recalled that the participation rate in the elections by public servants was very high, so the politician understands that learning from Macau's electoral experience serves as an example for mobilization in the Hong Kong elections, using “all efforts”. "All associations and entities in Hong Kong will organize electoral activities. I believe that there will be a great unprecedented mobilization and that Hong Kong society will show up [to vote]. Of course, the turnout rate will rise and surpass the numbers of previous elections", reads the opinion article. Concordant positions This opinion by Lo Man-tuen comes after the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office published an article last week highlighting the importance of holding elections in Hong Kong, warning of anti-China forces that could disturb the territory, interfering or even interrupting the election. Lo Man-tuen references this article, reporting that recently “several bizarre theories that interrupt the elections” have emerged, such as the “fabricated false allegation that there is ‘interference by the Central Government in the elections”, or when the “bless list [of candidates accepted by the Central Government] was released”. The author of the article also gives the example of speeches that boycott the elections. It should be remembered that the elections for the VIII LA of Macau ended on September 14th, registering an electoral participation of 11 percent more compared to the previous elections, in 2021, with 175,272 voters voting. This number of voters broke the historical record after 1999, when the administration of the territory passed from Portugal to China. The spokesperson for the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office spoke the day after the elections, speaking of the successful holding of the elections, something that was a “remarkable achievement in fully implementing the principle of ‘Macau governed by patriots’ and promoting a high-quality democracy that adapts to the real conditions of Macau”.

item.title: PJ | Indicted for kidnapping and rape of lover
item.description: The Judiciary Police (PJ) announced the arrest of a 34-year-old man on suspicion of kidnapping, rape and serious harm to the physical integrity of his lover. The case took place in a local hotel, after the two began an extramarital relationship last year. According to the PJ's version, the man and woman are from the interior, where they met and began a romantic relationship. However, the most recent meeting in Macau ended with the alleged commission of several crimes. After a meeting in a restaurant on Saturday morning, the woman was blackmailed into going to the man's hotel room in Macau. If she refused, the lover threatened to reveal the relationship to her husband and his entire family. The woman eventually gave in, but when she arrived at the hotel room she was raped and kidnapped for at least an hour. After the first attack, the woman contacted her sister to ask for help and ended up being attacked, with an ashtray on her head, in addition to being strangled with a cell phone charger cable. Given his injuries, the man allowed the victim to contact his sister, who in turn alerted the police. The suspect ended up being detained by the authorities, and when questioned by the authorities he asserted his right to silence.

item.title: FRC | Hu Jiawen exhibition to see from today
item.description: A Fundação Rui Cunha (FRC) apresenta hoje uma nova exposição. It is “Radiant Blue”, with works by Hu Jiawen, an artist who explores all her creativity in connection with the universe of Gongbi painting and other traditional Chinese painting techniques. To view until November 8th The artist Hu Jiawen presents today, at the Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC), several of her painting works, in a new exhibition open until the 8th of November. This is “Radiant Blue”, with its opening scheduled for today, starting at 6:30 pm, where “the spectator is invited to immerse themselves in a world where the traditional and the contemporary coexist, through the dialogue between the calm lines of meticulous brushwork and the intense metallic burns, of blue paint and gold leaf”, highlights the FRC, in a statement. This exhibition includes 30 works composed of Gongbi painting, traditional Chinese painting, experimental painting, contemporary painting, mixed media with metal foil, and bronze sculpture. Highlight is the “accurate selection” of works by the curator and renowned local artist, Chang Kuok Meng, in an exhibition organized by the FRC, the Macau Youth Art Association and the Macau Fine Arts Artists Association. According to the organization's manifesto, this solo exhibition is an “exploration of visual art rooted in meticulous traditional figure painting, integrating experimental techniques of Indian ink, blue printing and gold leaf burning”. Here, “the artist reconstructs oriental aesthetics from traditional and contemporary perspectives, creating an environment of painting on silk and rice paper, which embodies both classical meaning and modern consciousness”. Go beyond the usual According to Hu Jiawen, “Radiant Blue” reveals the “effort to leave the comfort zone and go beyond the label of ‘Gongbi Figure Painting'”, where the artist “uses different means” to try to “transmit the emotions and status of women in virtual and in-person spaces, hoping that the public will appreciate the beauty that arises from imperfection and transformation”. There are “female figures in the works that often exist in a space-time intertwined with reality and illusion”, showing “the delicate representation of meticulous brushwork”, or even “the transformative quality of experimental paint and the deep layers of blue printing”. These “are further highlighted by the intervention of burnt gold leaf, in the sense that its cracks and imperfections do not mean damage, but rather give the figures character and a sense of temporal texture”. Then there is “the light and hue created by the burnt gold leaf that suggest the fusion of emotions and the impression of memories”. Hu Jiawen has a bachelor's degree in Visual Arts Education from Macau Polytechnic University and a master's degree in Education from the University of Macau. Currently residing in the territory, she dedicates herself to artistic education and is employed by the Canton International Art Fair, in addition to performing other functions in various artistic organizations. His works have been exhibited in places such as Beijing, Guangzhou and Macau, receiving awards and being included in several collections. He is proficient in different genres, with a special talent for traditional Chinese painting, sketching, oil painting, engraving, ceramics, and fine brushstroke Gongbi figure painting.

item.title: Light Rail | Only two in every 100 young people use transport
item.description: Poor network coverage and the distance to residential areas mean that young people rarely use the metro. Among users, the main reason is the desire to have a different experience Only 1.5 percent of young people in Macau say they use the Light Rail as their main means of transport, that is, less than two out of every 100 young people. The conclusion is part of the study prepared by the New Chinese Youth Association of Macau, the results of which were presented yesterday. Based on a survey in which 647 young residents were questioned, aged between 18 and 44, the association concluded that the Light Rail is the least used means of transport of all those available in the territory. When asked to answer about the main means of transport in Macau, around 36.6 percent of respondents admitted that they mainly use buses. Private vehicles, such as cars or motorcycles, were indicated as the main means of travel for 31.9 percent of young people, while 26.3 percent responded that they traveled mainly on foot. Only 1.5 percent of those questioned indicated the metro as their main means of transport. Despite not being the main means of transport, 58.7 percent said they had used the metro at least once in the last year. However, almost seven in ten (68.4 percent) of these respondents were infrequent users, using every three months or less regularly. The Light Rail is still considered by users as “an experience” more than a form of transport that responds to everyday needs. Regarding the reason that led young people to choose the metro, 33.9 percent said that using it was justified “just by the experience”, while 22.1 percent said they would go to a border, and 21.3 percent said they would go to large hotels. Does not heat up or cool down Regarding the quality of the service, the largest group of young users are indifferent, with 39.3 percent responding that it is “neither good nor bad”. Conversely, 39.1 percent stated that satisfaction is “good or very good”. The results presented by the association do not allow us to know the total degree of dissatisfaction, however, there were also 14.2 percent of respondents who indicated that the experience on the metro was “not satisfactory” or “not very satisfying” Among young people who do not use the metro, 46.1 percent cited the fact that the “stations are too far from their homes” as the main reason, while 35.6 percent justified their non-use due to limited network coverage and 33.3 percent indicated that the metro does not provide direct access to the places they frequent most. One of the factors that also contributes to keeping young people away is the fact that payments made through applications that use QR technology are not accepted. Around 61.7 percent stated that due to this reason they feel less desire to use this transport. Currently, the Light Metro can be used by purchasing a ticket at ticket machines, which do not accept QR Code technology, but also at physical ticket offices. Those interested can also use the Macau Pass, passing directly through the access turnstiles.

item.title: Courts | Departure of Portuguese judge confirmed
item.description: Judge Rui Ribeiro will leave the Macao SAR courts starting next month. The information had been made public by Lusa, which cited the judge himself as a source, and was confirmed yesterday through an order, published in the Official Bulletin. “Judge Rui Carlos dos Santos Pereira Ribeiro is dismissed, at his request, from the position of judge of the Court of Second Instance of the Special Administrative Region of Macau […] from November 1, 2025”, the document reads. According to the news agency, Rui Ribeiro asked to return to Portugal, due to uncertainty about authorization from the Portuguese Superior Council of Judiciary (CSM) to continue in the Macao SAR. The judge has been in Macau since September 1, 2008, and in Portugal he is part of the Civil Section of the Court of Appeal of Guimarães. Last week, the president of the CSM, João Cura Mariano, showed his willingness to send more judges to Macau, despite admitting that there is also a lack of human resources in Portugal With Rui Ribeiro's departure, there is only one Portuguese judge left in Macau, Jerónimo Alberto Gonçalves Santos, who serves as president of a collective court at the Base Judicial Court (TJB). Jerónimo Santos has been in the Macao SAR courts since September 1, 2005, being part of the Intellectual Property, Competition, Regulation and Supervision section of the Lisbon Court of Appeal in Portugal.

item.title: Great Bay | Projected salary increases of 3% in Macau
item.description: In the most recent Greater Bay Area Remuneration and Benefits Survey Report 2025, 15.4 percent of 39 companies in Macau point to a salary increase of around 3 percent for 2026. The technology area is the one that pays the most to a recent graduate, with a salary of 19 thousand patacas Some data on the salary panorama and benefits granted to workers in the context of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area 2025 are now known, thanks to a new survey released on Friday. According to an official statement, Macau is represented by 39 companies surveyed, of which 15.4 percent expect a salary increase of three percent for next year. Meanwhile, there are “33 organizations that have not yet decided on expected salary increases”, and “no organization has indicated a salary freeze”. Forecasts for 2026 point to a salary adjustment of 3.1 percent in management or senior positions, supervisory positions or general staff, while employees in operational or customer service roles may receive increases of 3 percent. These are nicer numbers compared to this year, whose increase percentages are around 1.3 percent and 2.9 percent depending on the different professional positions. In 2022, the year of the pandemic, salary adjustments did not exceed 1 percent, and in senior or management personnel positions there was even a drop of 0.1 percent. Between the months of July 2024 and June 2025, there was an average salary increase of 1.6 percent in the 39 companies surveyed in Macau, while 24 reported a salary freeze. Excluding these companies that did not increase values, “the real average salary increase was, in general terms, in the remaining organizations, 3.4 percent”. These data refer to the 2025 Greater Bay Area Remuneration and Benefits Survey Report, which in the case of Macau includes companies linked to six sectors of activity, namely hotels and restaurants, banking, insurance, finance, culture and entertainment, or even commerce and engineering. The survey covered a total of 54,195 employees in Macau. Who pays more? The presentation of the Survey took place last Friday at the Faculty of Business Administration of the University of Macau (UM), and was carried out by this university, the Human Resources Association of the Greater Bay Area of ​​Macau and several higher education institutions in the Greater Bay Area, including the Human Resources Strategy and Development Center of the Faculty of Administration of the Hong Kong Baptist University, among others. Still in the case of Macau, it is highlighted that graduates in the area of ​​information technology are those with the highest salary at the beginning of their careers, in the order of 19 thousand patacas, while in Guangdong province, for the same type of work, a recent graduate earns around 6 thousand renminbis. If you have more advanced studies, such as a postgraduate degree or master's degree, the salary increases to 8,500 renminbis. In Guangdong province, the highest salaries for a recent graduate are in the area of ​​“R&D”, research and development of new products, with 6,500 renminbi. Those with more advanced studies than a bachelor's degree can reach a salary of 9,500 renimbis. In the case of Hong Kong, salaries for those just leaving university are higher in the engineering field, paying an average of 21,500 Hong Kong dollars currently. The survey was carried out in June this year among more than three thousand companies in the Greater Bay Area, and between the months of July and September 258 valid questionnaires were received: 39 from Macao SAR, 141 from Guangdong province and 78 from Hong Kong. In total, they cover 244 thousand employees who participated through an individualized panel system using artificial intelligence, entitled “My AI Salary Consultant”.

item.title: Kiang Wu | Association received 234.14 million patacas
item.description: The Kiang Wu Hospital Charitable Association received almost 9 out of every 10 patacas distributed in support by the Health Services in the third quarter. In total, 270.35 million patacas were allocated in subsidies The Kiang Wu Hospital Charity Association received 234.14 million patacas in subsidies paid by the Health Services, which in the third quarter of this year totaled 270.35 million patacas. The data was revealed last week, and means that for every 10 patacas distributed by the SS in support, practically nine end up deposited in the private hospital's accounts. The main supports were declared as “subsidy for the inpatient service”, referring to different months of the year, in a total of four subsidies. All of this support for the inpatient service amounted to more than 40 million patacas, with the highest amount being reached in May, with a tranche of 43.04 million patacas. In March, the amount was 41.74 million patacas, in July it dropped to 41.36 million patacas and in April it was 40.21 million patacas. These transfers represented 166.35 million patacas of the total 234.14 million received by the institution. The second largest type of support granted by the Health Services to Kiang Wu was due to the “protocol subsidy to finance the medical expenses of cardiac patients”. As part of this support, four monetary tranches were paid, corresponding to four months. In March, financing of medical expenses for cardiac patients reached the highest value, with a total of 12.70 million patacas. In May, the value was 9.87 million patacas, while in April it was 7.68 million patacas and in June 7.48 million patacas. Other smaller supports involved subsidizing the operation of the Hong Ling Center, expenses with examination services for cervical cancer screening, external vaccination consultations and subsidizing audit expenses for the Kiang Wu School of Nursing for the year 2023. Regular customers As for the associations supported by the SS, the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau (FAOM) received 18.37 million patacas, with the majority of the subsidies going to the rehabilitation nursing services of the Recovery Center. The SS granted the center three tranches of 4.57 million patacas, for the operation of the center in the months of July, August and September. Other support to FAOM aimed at “providing external consultation services”, with monthly support amounting to just over 1 million patacas. On the podium of the most supported institutions, the Tong Sin Tong Charitable Association also appears, receiving 9.48 million patacas. Among this support, the largest share was justified with the “provision of external consultation and treatment services” in the months of September, August and July. In all periods there was a fixed subsidy of 3.08 million patacas. However, there was also other smaller support, with subsidies of around 50 thousand patacas officially justified with a “fissure sealant program”. List of institutions The distribution of the 270.35 million patacas by the SS covered 12 local institutions. In the list, it is possible to find other associations such as Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Macau, which received around 103 thousand patacas, and Cáritas de Macau, to which 315 thousand patacas were distributed. In the case of these two institutions, the support was due to the provision of medical care in local nursing homes. The names of the supported institutions also include the New Chinese Youth Association of Macau, which received 5.17 million patacas, to support the recovery center in providing external consultations or cancer screening. This association also received a subsidy of 160 patacas, the lowest of those awarded, related to HIV virus screening tests.

item.title: Waldo and Emperor | Government coordinates changes for 182 workers
item.description: The satellite casinos Waldo and Emperor Palace, linked to Galaxy and Sociedade de Jogo de Macau, respectively, close this week, which will require changes to the gaming tables and the roles of 182 workers. The Gaming Inspection and Coordination Services Directorate says it is coordinating the situation with operators The Waldo and Emperor Palace casinos are permanently closing their doors this week. In the case of Waldo, linked to the Galaxy group, the closure is scheduled for Friday, 31st, at 11:59 pm, while the Emperor casino, linked to Sociedade de Jogo de Macau (SJM), will close on Thursday, 30th. The closing of these two gaming spaces occurs in the context of the end of satellite casinos by the end of the year, December 31st. In a statement, the Directorate of Gaming Inspection and Coordination Services (DICJ) promises to “strictly supervise the closure procedures of the aforementioned casinos, in order to ensure that they proceed in a stable and orderly manner and that all legal procedures are being duly complied with”. At issue are changes to the gaming tables and the roles of 182 workers, 71 at the Emperor Palace casino and 111 at Waldo. In a statement, Galaxy determined that Waldo's gaming tables “will be relocated to other casinos” under the group's operation, being “committed to safeguarding local employment”. In concrete terms, “members currently working at Waldo Casino will be transferred to other casinos or non-gaming related roles, based on operational needs, with all contractual terms of employment remaining unchanged”. Galaxy also promises to provide these workers with “a series of professional training programs to support their transition to new work environments and ensure continued professional stability”. As far as Emperor Palace is concerned, the same promise of “protecting local employment” also remains. All employees “will remain employed, being transferred to other company casinos to perform gaming-related functions, according to operational needs”, highlights SJM in a note. In the case of residents who work for Emperor and who are not directly hired by SJM Resorts, “they will be invited to apply for related vacancies within the group, with priority in hiring under equal circumstances, and will receive the necessary support, depending on the actual situation, to facilitate a smooth transition”, it is stated. The DICJ promises, in conjunction with the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs, “to ensure strict compliance with the commitments assumed by SJM and Galaxy, with regard to the relocation of the same workers, as well as effective guarantees regarding remuneration, benefits and working conditions”. Money to be traced Regarding the redemption of game chips, from Saturday, November 1st, “valid chips with the Galaxy Waldo logo can be redeemed at designated counters at Galaxy Macau Casino or StarWorld Casino”. In the case of the Emperor Palace casino, SJM describes that all gaming machines and tables “will be transferred to other company casinos in order to continue serving our valued customers”, while “customers who have chips, deposits or cash discounts accumulated at the Emperor Palace casino, and which have not been redeemed after its closure, will be able to visit other casinos operated by SJM Resorts from October 31st for follow-up agreements”, it reads. Regarding this aspect, the DICJ promises to “designate employees to supervise, ‘in loco’, the formal closure process, ensuring compliance with the procedures with regard to the appropriate treatment of cash and game chips stored in the treasury”, among other matters.

item.title: Exhibition on intangible cultural heritage at the Macau Museum
item.description: A new exhibition on the intangible cultural heritage of the Greater Bay Area opens to the public this Saturday, entitled “A New Impulse – Cultivated Greater Bay Area, A Brilliant Intangible Cultural Heritage: Exhibition of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area”. The initiative can be seen at the Macau Museum until March 15th next year. Organized with several museum entities in the province of Guangdong and Hong Kong, the exhibition “will encompass a thematic exhibition, interactive demonstrations of artisanal techniques, workshops and the sale of cultural and creative products related to intangible cultural heritage”. The exhibition presents “more than 50 manifestations representative of the intangible cultural heritage of the Greater Bay Area, including Cantonese embroidery, colored paper crafts, wood carvings and Cantonese porcelain”. The aim is, in this way, “to make the public aware of the artisanal techniques of the intangible cultural heritage in the traditional cultural context of Lingnan, as well as the oriental aesthetics formed through the fusion of Chinese and Western cultures, as evidenced in the intangible cultural heritage of the Greater Bay Area”. The great interaction In connection with the opening of this exhibition, there will be “interactive demonstrations of artisanal techniques” on the weekend, Saturday and Sunday, in places such as the Fortaleza do Monte garden and the Macau Museum. These demonstrations cover various arts, including Foshan Chinese New Year woodblock painting, Hakka qilin dancing from Hang Hau in Sai Kung, Portuguese tile making and painting, Portuguese folk dance and lion dance. Also included are demonstrations of Wing Chun martial arts, Choi Lei Fat martial arts, Naamyam Narrative Songs, Taoist ritual music and Baatyam percussion. The entire program can be seen on the Macau Museum portal. The workshops will also take place on the 1st and 2nd of November, at the Macau Museum, Casa do Mandarin and Zheng Guanying Memorial Museum, focusing on puppet theater for the whole family, creating bookmarks made with gold thread embroidery or even creating Cantonese opera accessories. A highlight is the holding, this Saturday, of two guided tour sessions at the exhibition. The deadline for registering for some activities is Wednesday, which can be done on the Macau Single Account platform. In addition to all the activities mentioned above, between Saturday and Monday, the sale of cultural and creative products related to intangible cultural heritage will take place in the garden of Fortaleza do Monte. This exhibition is “the first large-scale traveling exhibition dedicated to the intangible cultural heritage of the Greater Bay Area”, and the first edition, entitled “Celebrating National Day - Auspicious Intangible Cultural Heritage of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area”, was held in Hong Kong in October last year. Earlier this year the same exhibition was held in Shenzhen, called “New Year in Shenzhen: Grand Gathering in the Greater Bay Area”.

item.title: Diplomacy | Trump wants to make a good deal with China
item.description: The President of the United States, Donald Trump, stated yesterday that he hopes to “reach a good agreement” during the next meeting with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, including a pact related to the TikTok platform, according to the international press. Trump declared, aboard Air Force One, that TikTok will be one of the topics he will discuss with Xi during the meeting, scheduled for this Thursday, on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit, which will take place in the South Korean city of Gyeongju, according to the EFE news agency. According to the US President, the agreement, signed between Washington and the parent company of the popular video platform, the Chinese ByteDance, already has Xi's “provisional approval”. In September, the United States reached an agreement with Beijing-backed ByteDance to allow TikTok to continue operating on North American soil, after the US Congress established in 2024 that the application should be deactivated due to the risk it posed to the country's national security. The pact establishes the creation of a mostly North American joint venture, with an operation sufficiently separate from its Chinese parent company — which will maintain a 20 percent stake —, especially with regard to the Chinese Government's access to servers that store user data. The face-to-face meeting between the two leaders will provide an opportunity for both powers to ease tensions following Beijing's announcement of restrictions on the sale of its rare earths and to discuss a possible comprehensive trade agreement after months of tariff tensions.

item.title: HK | Smuggling case worth 200 million dollars discovered
item.description: Shark fins, cigars, cell phones, pharmaceutical products and even donkey skin. These are the products discovered in two more smuggling cases discovered by the Hong Kong Customs Service (SA) on the 3rd and 7th of this month. According to a statement from this organization, the value of the goods is around 200 million US dollars, with two ships involved, one of them destined for river trade. This ship was destined for Macau and was caught by the authorities on October 3rd. Five containers destined for Taiwan were also inspected and were declared to be transporting frozen food. On October 7, the SA in Hong Kong realized that 150 tons of donkey skin were circulating here and not the declared food. The same statement indicates that the investigation continues and that “the possibility of arrests is not excluded”. Under Hong Kong's Import and Export Law, anyone found guilty of importing or exporting undeclared cargo is subject to a maximum fine of US$2 million and a seven-year prison sentence upon conviction. Seven cases last week Taking into account the holding of the National Games starting next month, the Customs Service (SA) wants to show service and admitted to having reinforced inspection efforts at the Portas do Cerco Border Post. As a result of these efforts, seven cases of smuggling were recorded between 21 and 25 October. According to a statement from the SA of Macau, within the scope of the seven cases, customs agents found a total of 120 old cell phones, often used to circumvent internet access limitations, 85 pieces of electronic products and 1344 grams of cigar. The smugglers involved residents of Macau and the Interior, aged between 38 and 64. Those involved were fined, the SA announced, under the provisions of the foreign trade law.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Yelu Abaoji (872-926), the head of the nomadic Khitan people, a word translated as Qidan, contrary to tradition, decided to establish in his vast territory in 916 a dynasty in the style of the disintegrated Tang dynasty (618-907) and all the others that preceded it, with the succession of the maximum leader becoming hereditary and not a choice by a council tribal. He even went so far as, once again going against nomadic tradition, to build a «Supreme capital», Shangjing, Linhuangfu, designed in a grid pattern with streets aligned in the style of Chang’an, the capital of the Tang. And although it was the tribal military who made the decisions, Han civilians were chosen for state administration. He called this State Da Qidan and was posthumously given the title of Taizu Tian Huangdi, “Heavenly Emperor Taizu”. His successor would change the name of the dynasty to Liao and despite subsequent setbacks, this would be the name that would prevail. Abaoji had a son, Yelu Bei (899-937), whom he named Crown Prince and gave the title Renhuang Wang, «Imperial King of Men», handing him over the governance of the kingdom of Dongdan. And when the time for succession arrived, Yelu Bei naturally expected to inherit his father's title, but his mother, the ruthless Empress Dowager Shulu Ping (879-953), had other plans and with cold blood and cunning made the succession fall to another of her sons. What was improbable followed in Yelu Bei's life would be remembered years later by the poet, calligrapher and painter of the Yuan dynasty, Zhu Derun (1294-1365). Next to the figure of a horseman on a swift ride in the Deer Hunt on a horizontal scroll that was attributed to Yelu Bei (ink and color on paper, 24.6 x 79.9 cm, in the Metmuseum) he wrote: «To escape the persecution of Yelu Deguang (r. as Liao Taizong, 927-947) he crossed the sea and arrived at Dengzhou (in Shandong) and there he paid allegiance to Emperor Mingzong (r.925-933) of the Late Tang (923-936) and in return was granted the name Li and the commandership of Huaihai.” Li Zanhua would therefore be the name that Yelu Bei would use from then on. A name – Li – of enormous prestige because this was the name of the ruling family during the Tang dynasty, offered by Emperor Xianzong (r.805-820) to the founders of that second of the Five Dynasties period as a reward for their loyalty and which they carried, like the name Tang, with pride. Li Zanhua, wrote Zhu Derun, “used to take paintings and books with him when he traveled. He liked to paint knights with bows, on hunts or excursions. His clothes and accessories followed the rustic conventions of the barbarians because that was what he was used to and felt comfortable with. The way he used the brush was soft and fine while the dynamism of the men and horses corresponds to the spirit of the 8th century Tang. A painting that deserves to be appreciated.”

item.title: Today Macau
item.description: The Chinese Government defended yesterday that China and Germany must maintain relations based on “mutual respect, equal treatment and mutually beneficial cooperation”, after the postponement of a visit by the German Foreign Minister. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Guo Jiakun declared, at a press conference, that Beijing “has always developed ties with Berlin from a strategic and long-term perspective”. Guo stressed that, as “large countries and leading world economies”, China and Germany maintain a “mutually beneficial” cooperative relationship. “Under the current circumstances, both parties must continue to push their ties in the right direction,” he added. The German Ministry of Foreign Affairs confirmed last week the postponement of Johann Wadephul's visit, scheduled for October 28th and 29th, after the Chinese side did not confirm further meetings beyond the meeting with his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi. German diplomacy spokeswoman Kathrin Deschauer expressed Berlin's “great concern” about the restrictions imposed by Beijing on the export of certain components used in the production of semiconductors and rare earth materials, measures that raised alarm in the German automotive industry. Trade tensions between the two countries intensified after the intervention of the Dutch State in the chip manufacturer Nexperia, a subsidiary of the Chinese Wingtech, which led Beijing to restrict exports of crucial components for the sector. The ban is generating concern among the Volkswagen Group, Europe's largest car manufacturer.
